quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: NewBank is bigger than Coinbase, Robinhood, Affirm, SoFi, and Lemonade combined. 80% to 90% of NewBank's growth is through word of mouth.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A striking scale and growth-channel data point that underscores the power of product-led, word-of-mouth growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We're not trying to be incrementally better, we are trying to be fundamentally different. We want our customers to love us fanatically.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A clear product strategy principle: aim for category-defining differentiation and intense customer love rather than marginal improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We built a lending product, we built an investment product, we built an insurance product, we built a series of small business products. We rarely scale a project until we know the Sean Ellis score hit a threshold that we find really compelling.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for product line expansion: launch multiple bets but only scale after hitting a strong product-market-fit metric threshold.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Kevin Systrom in the early days of Instagram, I heard him say it at a conference. We may not be right, but at least we are clear. Even if your strategy isn't right, you have a very clear idea of what was supposed to be happening.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A mental model for strategy-making: prioritize clarity so you can learn and iterate faster even when the initial strategy is wrong.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and skim provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Work OS)
quotes.context: Highlights a predictable inflection point for SaaS teams: enterprise customer demands drive the need for specific capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale, while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Work OS)
quotes.context: A practical system-design principle: optimize for both scale and flexibility in authorization models.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Most founders and finance teams have to couple together a patchwork of tools to reconcile transactions from different sources, work extra hard just to get a holistic view of cash flow and have maps to company priorities, and struggle to get answers from platforms that all speak different languages.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Mercury)
quotes.context: Captures a common operational failure mode—tool fragmentation—framing the problem practitioners can address.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Apply in minutes at Mercury.com, and join over 200,000 ambitious startups like mine that trust Mercury to get them to perform at their best.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Mercury)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point (“over 200,000”) that signals market validation and scale.

quotes.topic_title: Nubank mind-blowing stats and word of mouth
quotes.text: So one, NewBank is bigger than Coinbase, Robinhood, Affirm, SoFi, and Lemonade combined.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A striking comparative benchmark that quickly conveys Nubank’s scale versus well-known fintech peers.

quotes.topic_title: Nubank mind-blowing stats and word of mouth
quotes.text: 80% to 90% of new Bank's growth is through word of mouth.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete growth-channel data point that frames product-led/viral growth as the core driver worth studying.

quotes.topic_title: Nubank mind-blowing stats and word of mouth
quotes.text: Three, NewBank has more customers than Bank of America, which is one of the four big banks in the US, while also only operating in three countries in Latin America.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive scale example showing massive customer adoption despite limited geographic footprint.

quotes.topic_title: Nubank mind-blowing stats and word of mouth
quotes.text: We've recently set a new world record for the first underwater credit card transaction, so we're always looking for some fun things to do there.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A memorable brand-stunt example illustrating how unusual, talk-worthy moments can reinforce word-of-mouth.

quotes.topic_title: Nubank mind-blowing stats and word of mouth
quotes.text: So my sense is the reason that NewBank thrived and made it is, there's this obsession with building a product that customers are fanatical about.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear product principle tying exceptional customer love to organic growth outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Building products customers love fanatically
quotes.text: But first I would say, really think hard and tap into a very deep pain point. The large incumbent Brazilian banks were amongst the most profitable in the world, they were also amongst the most hated in the world.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A clear product strategy: start with a deep, emotionally charged pain point—especially where incumbents are hated despite strong economics.

quotes.topic_title: Building products customers love fanatically
quotes.text: We want our customers to love us fanatically.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A memorable cultural North Star that operationalizes “customer obsession” into an explicit bar for product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Building products customers love fanatically
quotes.text: And when there are hard decisions to be made, we bias in favor of the customer. The customer's love, will they want to tell their friends, and neighbors, and family about it?
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: An actionable decision rule for tradeoffs: choose the option that maximizes customer love and word-of-mouth advocacy.

quotes.topic_title: Building products customers love fanatically
quotes.text: You make sure that that discovery is focused not simply on asking the customer, but on innovating on their behalf.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A counterintuitive discovery principle: don’t just ask users—interpret needs and create solutions they can’t articulate.

quotes.topic_title: Building products customers love fanatically
quotes.text: You've got to observe them, and find their pain points even when they aren't noticing it.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A practical methodology: use observation to uncover latent pain points that interviews and surveys often miss.

quotes.topic_title: Company values and operationalizing customer obsession
quotes.text: We want our customers to love us fanatically.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A crisp, memorable north-star value that sets an unusually high bar for customer obsession.

quotes.topic_title: Company values and operationalizing customer obsession
quotes.text: We love the Amazon mock press release technique. Explain to me before we've put a single engineer on the project, not explain to me actually, explain to the intended customer why they should care. Because if you can't tell me in two paragraphs why the customer you're building this for should care, then there's still work to do.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A concrete pre-build mechanism to force customer clarity before investing engineering time.

quotes.topic_title: Company values and operationalizing customer obsession
quotes.text: We do have product and design reviews several times a week where we're asking ourselves that question, why is this great for the customer? Why is this fundamentally different for the customer? How does this redefine the category that we are thinking about on the dimensions of quality, on the dimensions of complexity, on the dimensions of price, and usually on the dimensions of all three of those at the same time?
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A repeatable review cadence and question set to test whether work is truly “fundamentally different” versus incremental.

quotes.topic_title: Company values and operationalizing customer obsession
quotes.text: We rarely scale a project, a product we've launched, until we know the Sean Ellis score and we know that it's hit a threshold that we find really compelling.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A specific gating metric (Sean Ellis score) used as a hard check before scaling, countering the tendency to scale too early.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring love: Sean Ellis score, NPS, churn
quotes.text: We rarely scale a project, a product we've launched, until we know the Sean Ellis score and we know that it's hit a threshold that we find really compelling.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A clear gating rule: don’t scale until a specific PMF metric clears a high bar.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring love: Sean Ellis score, NPS, churn
quotes.text: But at each stage you ask them, how disappointed would you be if this product went away?
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable PMF survey question teams can run at every launch stage.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring love: Sean Ellis score, NPS, churn
quotes.text: Now we've had to do some things in NewBank, Brazilians are a culturally happier group than the global average. So for us, our threshold isn't 40%, we've generally moved it up to 50%. I don't believe we have product market fit unless 50% of Brazilians are telling us they would be very disappointed, because Brazilians are inherently polite.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Counterintuitive but practical: adjust “standard” PMF thresholds for cultural response bias.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring love: Sean Ellis score, NPS, churn
quotes.text: But there have been, for example, in Mexico, we've recorded an NPS when we launched the first couple of years of 94-95.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark showing how extreme “world-class” NPS targets can be in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring love: Sean Ellis score, NPS, churn
quotes.text: We also look at metrics like churn to make sure that we're not building a leaky bucket, and that's part of this viral customer acquisition loop that we've built.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Connects retention (churn) directly to word-of-mouth growth loops—viral only works if the bucket isn’t leaking.

quotes.topic_title: Using cohorts to raise product-market-fit scores
quotes.text: my push to the team is what are the three, four, five things you need to build to really get decisively beyond 50? And what are the segments or cohorts where it is above 50, and what is that telling us versus the cohorts where it's lower than that?
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A practical cohort-based method for using PMF survey scores to diagnose what to build next and where the product is truly resonating.

quotes.topic_title: Using cohorts to raise product-market-fit scores
quotes.text: "Good enough, isn't good enough. Is it great enough?"
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A memorable bar-raising heuristic for deciding whether a product is ready to launch or needs more iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Using cohorts to raise product-market-fit scores
quotes.text: But we found that there was a small cohort of a customer base who had more than four plus commitments registered. And even more so within that small cohort an even smaller bullseye cohort who had more than four commitments on at least two of the four rails. And their Sean Ellis score hit 70% and we're like, "Okay, the key is we need to across these rails, not have them one by one. And we need to make it easy for customers to onboard multiple bills across multiple rails."
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A concrete example of finding a 'bullseye cohort' with very high love and then scaling that experience by improving cross-rail onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: Using cohorts to raise product-market-fit scores
quotes.text: On the surface if you said to the average person anywhere, any sort of developed country, we're going to have a bill auto-pay, that's on the face of it not necessarily exciting, but if you build it right, it is actually a fundamentally different experience rather than incrementally better experience.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that even 'boring' features can create step-change value if designed as a fundamentally different experience.

quotes.topic_title: Using cohorts to raise product-market-fit scores
quotes.text: So we just tell them, call 10 of them. Pick up the phone yourself. Don't ask a researcher to come up with a plan to go do the research to then summarize it, to then bring it to you, which has so many degrees of distance built in. You pick up the phone, call 10 of them and nine times out of 10, by the time you've made your fifth call, you could predict what's customer six, seven, eight, nine and 10 are going to tell you.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Tactical guidance for speeding up learning loops by having PMs/designers directly call a small number of bullseye users instead of running heavyweight research.

quotes.topic_title: Direct customer calls and fast feedback loops
quotes.text: We literally pick up the phone.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Directly advocates the simplest, fastest way to reduce distance from customers and accelerate learning.

quotes.topic_title: Direct customer calls and fast feedback loops
quotes.text: Because you can get tone of voice. Brazilians and Mexicans are incredibly expressive. There is a degree of real fine grain sense that the statistics never tell you.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Highlights the qualitative nuance (tone, emotion) that can’t be captured in dashboards and surveys.

quotes.topic_title: Direct customer calls and fast feedback loops
quotes.text: We're just like, just make the call. Make it as simple, as unobtrusive with as little overhead as possible to make sure the voice of the customer is coming directly into the teams that are building.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A lightweight operating principle for building fast feedback loops without heavy research process.

quotes.topic_title: Direct customer calls and fast feedback loops
quotes.text: And one of the things I try to say frequently within the walls of Nubank is we are not going to take a small problem and scale it because if we do that, we end up with a big mess.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A scaling guardrail: don’t amplify unresolved issues—fix them at small scale first.

quotes.topic_title: Direct customer calls and fast feedback loops
quotes.text: Whereas you can pour a lot of money and a lot of effort and when you have a big app like Nubank or places like Google and Facebook, you can make any product look great for months if not years because you have such a large customer base that you can always get them to try it with all sorts of basic techniques, but you're bouncing a dead cat.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that distribution can mask lack of product-market fit, creating bigger downstream cleanup.

quotes.topic_title: PM courage: pushing back and not scaling problems
quotes.text: If you really don't think it's going to work, don't tell me what I want to hear.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A crisp pushback principle: PMs should prioritize truth over pleasing stakeholders when they believe a plan will fail.

quotes.topic_title: PM courage: pushing back and not scaling problems
quotes.text: It's incumbent on you, it's expected of you as an owner to tell me the bad news and tell it to me early, even when it's convenient, even when there's a promotion at stake, these dynamics get very real very quickly then look, I don't think it's going to work and here's why, or it's not working and here's why, or we should kill it and here's why.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Defines an ownership culture standard and an actionable script for delivering early, high-stakes pushback with reasons.

quotes.topic_title: PM courage: pushing back and not scaling problems
quotes.text: And so I would just encourage people to try it, understand the trade-offs, understand the challenge, articulate the other side, but if you genuinely believe it's not yet ready to scale your products, at the end of the day, the big mess is a thing you're still going to owe and we're all going to forget that we told you to scale the thing. We're all going to still blame you at the end of the day.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A counterintuitive accountability reminder: scaling prematurely won’t protect you—ownership means you’ll still be held responsible for the fallout.

quotes.topic_title: PM courage: pushing back and not scaling problems
quotes.text: So you might as well bite the bullet earlier, pivot it when it's easier to do and it'll work out better in the end.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Actionable timing advice: push for earlier pivots because change is cheaper and outcomes improve when you act before scaling.

quotes.topic_title: Doing customer research well: hypotheses and observation
quotes.text: First off, per your Jeff Bezos anecdote, the anecdote usually trumps the data.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A reminder to keep real customer stories central, even when sophisticated analysis is available.

quotes.topic_title: Doing customer research well: hypotheses and observation
quotes.text: The second one that I believe very, very strongly in is I think teams often skip the step of clearly, very, very clearly working very hard to be super crisp in articulating their hypothesis.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A practical research discipline: start with a crisp hypothesis so findings can validate or invalidate something specific.

quotes.topic_title: Doing customer research well: hypotheses and observation
quotes.text: The third one is, I've got a hypothesis, I've got it really crisp and now the pitfall is I've fallen in love with my hypothesis. I'm a lawyer for my hypothesis. I'm not a judge of whether the hypothesis is right or not right.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for avoiding confirmation bias during customer research.

quotes.topic_title: Doing customer research well: hypotheses and observation
quotes.text: And then the last thing I would highlight is even when you have a strong hypothesis and you're actually in the mode of doing the research, observe more than ask questions if you can, ask indirect questions more than direct questions.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Tactical interviewing guidance: prioritize observation and indirect questioning to uncover real pain instead of leading answers.

quotes.topic_title: Doing customer research well: hypotheses and observation
quotes.text: We have a hypothesis at Nubank that the joint bank account, I was doing some research on this just last week. The joint bank account was invented in the early, it's actually hard to say, but it was invented, depending on what source you believe, in the late 19th or early 20th century.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A concrete example of using historical context as a hypothesis generator for rethinking legacy products.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practical expectation-setting insight: assume real-world customer data will be messy and design import flows accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And building a spreadsheet importer becomes a never-ending sink for your engineering and support resources.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Warns practitioners that DIY CSV/spreadsheet importers can turn into ongoing operational drag, not a one-time build.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You keep adding features to your spreadsheet importer, but customers keep running into issues.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Captures a common product trap: incremental improvements don’t necessarily solve core usability problems in messy-data ingestion.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Six months later you're fixing yet another date conversion edge case bug.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of the long-tail maintenance burden that comes with handling messy CSV edge cases.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers get frustrated by useless messages like error online 53 and never end up getting started with your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Emphasizes an actionable UX lesson: poor error messaging in onboarding/import flows can directly prevent activation.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy: clarity, focus, and coherent bets
quotes.text: Great execution multiplied by a poor strategy is a waste of everyone's time.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A crisp reminder that execution can’t compensate for unclear or wrong strategic direction.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy: clarity, focus, and coherent bets
quotes.text: "We may not be right, but at least we are clear."
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Highlights clarity as a strategic advantage because it speeds learning and course-correction even when the plan is imperfect.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy: clarity, focus, and coherent bets
quotes.text: Strategy isn't an ambitious goal, it's not an aspiration, it's not a set of financial outcomes. It is a coherent plan for how you going to apply your strengths in a leveraged way against a core important problem.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Defines strategy in an actionable way that practitioners can use to distinguish real strategy from vision or targets.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy: clarity, focus, and coherent bets
quotes.text: Now that is a coherent description of a very specific problem for a very specific set of customers with a very specific solution based on a very specific advantage.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Shows what “coherence” looks like in practice: tightly linking customer, problem, solution, and advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy: clarity, focus, and coherent bets
quotes.text: concentration is what builds wealth, diversification is what preserves wealth. And you're a startup. You're not trying to preserve anything. You're trying to build something. It requires concentrated bets, not hedging.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A counterintuitive mental model for startups: focus beats hedging because the goal is growth, not risk minimization.

quotes.topic_title: Building strategic muscle and being fundamentally different
quotes.text: One is taking it seriously.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Emphasizes that strategic skill-building starts with treating strategy as a core discipline, not an afterthought.

quotes.topic_title: Building strategic muscle and being fundamentally different
quotes.text: And having those frameworks, all of which in many ways, if you synthesize them, are getting at the same thing around focus, around a clear understanding of the customer, around not trying to be in the words that we literally have on Nubank coffee mugs, "We're not trying to be incrementally better. We are trying to be fundamentally different."
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Connects strategy frameworks to a concrete operating mantra that forces focus and differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Building strategic muscle and being fundamentally different
quotes.text: Hedging is appealing. Hedging means you don't have to make choices. Hedging sounds smart. Concentrating all your bets is the thing that desperate people do, and startups are desperate entities because they're burning cash in almost every instance.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take that reframes focus as necessary (even if it looks “desperate”) and hedging as avoidance of real choices.

quotes.topic_title: Building strategic muscle and being fundamentally different
quotes.text: I'm very wary, given the places I've worked, of the successful company with one or two monster products, and Nubank is now in that fortunate position, that starts to get conservative, that starts to forget that focus, concentration, customer obsession are every bit as important, that even though the company won't go bankrupt if products three, four, five and six don't succeed because products one and two are monster cashflow drivers, that's a slow path to death.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Warns that success can erode strategic discipline—especially when cash-cow products reduce the urgency to focus and obsess over customers.

quotes.topic_title: Building strategic muscle and being fundamentally different
quotes.text: Not every single thing of the hundred things you launch in a year can be fundamentally different, but we're searching for those anchors that are going to be fundamentally different all the time around which you build some sustaining innovation as well, but we are in the fundamentally different business, not the incrementally better business.
quotes.speaker: Jag Duggal
quotes.context: Provides a practical differentiation methodology: pick a few “anchors” to be fundamentally different, and surround them with sustaining incremental improvements.
